course.subject: MECH
course.name: Statics and Dynamics
course.description: Fundamental course on the analysis of the equilibrium and dynamic behavior of mechanical systems. Statics: equilibrium of particles and of rigid bodies; distributed forces; analysis of structures, including, trusses, frames, cables and beams. Dynamics: kinematics of particles; kinetics of particles, Newton's second law, energy, momenta, impact dynamics; systems of particles; kinematics of rigid bodies; kinetics of rigid bodies in two and three dimensions. For students with major in MECH, AE and MEGBM only.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1023) AND (PHYS 1111 OR PHYS 1112 OR PHYS 1312)

reviews.author: Midnight919
reviews.comment_content: Fairly similar to high school physics or the Kinematics content in IB Physics. It covers topics such as reaction forces, torque/moment, and kinematics. Yet, providing a broader and in depth analysis regarding said topics with calculus or other relevant mathematical skills. A build up of necessary pre-requisite skills for taking Solid Mechanics (MECH 2040) later on.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin is a very passionate lecturer and he thoroughly goes through each example question which are found in all of his lecture slides. Online materials which aid understanding are not provided but additional practice questions can be found on Canvas.

The method which he teaches the course content and notes referenced within the lecture slides may not be adequate to many individuals. It is recommended to refer to the course followed textbook to fully grasp the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for this course is fairly loose and lenient compared to other MECH courses. However, the major drawback of the course is that the content is relatively easy compared to other courses, hence, the assignments and quizzes typically score a high mean. Therefore, the achieved grade in the end may not reflect your performance throughout the course.

During the semester which I had taken the course, the final exam was canceled and replaced with a timed, open-book, handwritten, online submitted assignment. Hence, I am uncertain about the difficulty of the final exam.

Assignments: 20% (4% each)
In-class Quizzes: 30% (10% each)
Final Exam: 50%

Overall Achieved Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course is fairly low. However, there will be spikes (self initiated) prior to the date of in-class quizzes.

There are only 5 assignments/homework exercises which each contain roughly 3 questions per assignment. However, each assignment is straight forward to complete if you are able to follow the taught content.

The assignments are handed out bi-weekly and are given one week from the distributed date to complete.

reviews.author: KWing
reviews.title: An easy course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Statics: equilibrium of particles and of rigid bodies; distributed
forces; analysis of structures, including, trusses, frames, and
beams

2. Dynamics: kinematics of particles; kinetics of particles, Newton's
second law, energy, momentum, impact dynamics; systems of
particles; kinematics of rigid bodies; kinetics of rigid bodies in
two and three dimensions.

The concepts are from high school physics but the calculations are more complicated, so you need to be careful. Also, some simple calculus are involved and they are really important because nearly half of the dynamics questions in final exam required us to do calculus. Don't miss that :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ma explains everything clearly. You don't even need to ask him questions. Also, he has done a lot of questions with us during lessons and, most of the time, he taught us how to do them step-by-step.

But the tutorials were not quite useful. The TAs were just doing the questions without teaching you how to do them. However, the answers were uploaded after the tutorial, so nothing needs to be worried about.
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Assignments – 20%
3 online quizzes – 45% (60 minutes each)
F2F final exam– 35% (3 hours)

I got full marks in all assignments and 95/100 in all quizzes. Since all courses from MAE Department will not announce the marks of final exam, I don't know the result. I got an A at the end.

p.s. he said only the top 20% can get into A range, but seems like quite a lot of people are in A range.

p.s. The marking scheme of the quizzes are weird. I got the answers and some steps wrong but they just deducted 5 marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Assignment
· 2-3 questions per assignment
· mainly focus on statics
(but I think dynamics is more difficult, so I don't understand why they did this)

All the assignments are not difficult, even if you really don't know how to do them, you can still find the answers from the internet.

2. Quiz and Exam
· 2-3 questions per quiz
( All quizzes mainly focused on statics)
· 6-8 questions in exam (half half)

The quizzes and exam are not difficult, sometimes they are easier than the supplementary exercises and questions from tutorials, so you just need to finish them and you will be able to get a nice grade.

THE MOST IMPORTANT THING is both TAs and professor are lazy. They just reuse the questions from past assignments, quizzes and exams again and again and make some minor changes. If you really have no time to study, some free past paper websites can help you. You don't even need to purchase sources from seniors.

reviews.author: Yoyo Lam
reviews.comment_content:
It comprises of two parts, static and dynamic. Both are relatively easy, most of it is just high school physics.

In static, you would be calculating just F=ma for most of the time, calculating the force of the component in the truss. Just need to be careful when deriving the equations.

In dynamic, you would be calculation motion, including velocity, acceleration, momentum, energy, and Newton's law.

It should be the easiest course in the MAE curriculum. But if you are so eager in studying, you may be a bit disappointed since there are not many things to learn in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin is a great tutor. I have never seen a professor as patient as him. The pace of the lessons is extremely slow, you may be a bit impatient during the lessons sometimes. He really explains step by step and does the questions together with you.

I really recommend taking the lectures, doing the question together with him, although sometimes you may feel he is too slow, you would understand and be able to solve the questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is fair, quite a good grading compared with other mech courses. Robin is nice.

The question in the exam is similar to the one in the lecture notes and they are not that hard.

In this semester, we have all exams in online mode. Robin is so fair that he draws all the questions himself by hand to avoid cheating. I really appreciate that.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload. 4 assignments, 3 quizzes with a final.

If you really attend the lesson and do the questions with him during the classes and do the homework by yourself, I think there are not many things for you to revise and you don't really need to take a lot of time studying before the exam.

I think this is the lowest workload course already in all the mech courses.

reviews.author: HKG_SIGMA
reviews.title: WTF?
reviews.comment_content:
Fundamental concepts for mechanical engineering.

Statics: Total Force (in x y z directions) = 0
             Total Moment (in cw/acw directions) = 0

Dynamics: a=dv/dt
                  v=ds/dt

Basically these are what spend (bother) you the whole semester. Not difficult to understand if you have studied PHYS before.

reviews.comment_grading: TBH, pretty bad compared to previous terms. The mean was around 54 out of 100 in the midterm. This may be because of the changes in questions. Very tough! It's also a factor which a very minor fault in your answers may deduct 15 marks out of 30 from a question.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy. 5 assignments throughout the semester. 1 midterm and 1 final.

reviews.author: Alphor
reviews.title: Slightly difficult topics with a very enthusiastic instructor
reviews.comment_content:
As the topic says, 80% Statics, and 20% Dynamics.
Working with forces and acceleration of Trusses.

Basically F=ma to the roof,
and sprinkle some a = v^2 / r.

Basic Trigonometry and Linear Algebra skills are very important in this course. Practice working with Triangles and 3 equations - 3 unknowns can help a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very enthusiastic, fun and caring professor. Even got a tablet just so the students at the back could see better. Patient with questions and a consultation period is available after every lecture. May be a bit fast in teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: Lenient grades. But people are competitive (Quizzes Mean can reach up to 93%).

reviews.author: P.T
reviews.title: Do as much exercise as you can, then you will get a good grade

- this course will be easy if your geometry is good since there are lots of angles

-need to draw free body diagram, sin law cos law need to be used frequently

reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin teaching style is definitely my type. He is very friendly, play music before class and quiz.

He will do lots of exercise with us during the class, also giving lots of example and exercises for us for practising. He does it almost every class. Honestly, skipping class occationally like me will still be fine. But you do need to read back or watch back recording.

BTW, He is definitely not a killer:)
reviews.comment_grading:
15% for HW
45%for 3 quizzes (60 mins each)
40% for final exam (3 hrs)

- For assignment, most ppl got full marks. mean At least 90%. Not difficult

- For quizzes, mean is around 60-70%( not so sure)
It is not difficult if you have done some exercises in lecture notes or from Robin's. Some questions are very similar. And there are only 3 questions in each quiz.

- For exam, It is obviously more difficult than quizzes. Doing insufficient exercise will be doomed. Really need to think in exam. In quiz, many ppl early leave, but final not much. You can imagine the difficulty. But doing sufficient exercise will be fine. Also, no need to worry about time. 3 hours is more than enough.

reviews.author: ernestlweeeee
reviews.title: Easy course (tldr: do hw, revise a little for quiz, get rest and relax for final exam)
reviews.comment_content:
If you've taken MECH 1906 or CIVL 1100, you'll be fine.

This course talks about forces in equilibrium, objects in motion and vectors, but to simplify its just high school physics (Mechanics) mixed with calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I'm sorry Robin but your style of teaching is just not my type. Great person, plays music before class, very friendly, but not my style of teaching sadly.

Extensive problem analysis and step-by-step solving in class, but then he does it almost every class so stuff that needs to be learnt get taught with gaps in between.

If you like doing exercise in class with the professor, then he'll be great for you. Otherwise, just skip classes like me(skipped like two-thirds of the semester lmao) and read the lecture notes from time to time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very distributed grading system
15% for HW
45%(???) for 3 quizzes
40% for final exam

Its not that hard unironically, except for final exam, so you'll get good grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 assignments, 3 questions each, easy enough if you go through the lecture notes, doesn't take much time to complete as well.

3 quizzes, 3 questions, they're fairly simple so do some revision and you'll be fine. Alternatively, questions may be identical to previous semesters so look at past quizzes if you don't want to revise.

Final exam was reasonably more difficult than the quizzes, but you have 3 hours to solve 7 questions so don't worry about time. Doing more revision probably won't help much, so keep a clear mind, get enough rest, get enough food, and relax.

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Good Teaching for Dull Content
reviews.comment_content:
MECH2020 is divided into statics and dynamics, in which a major focus is placed on statics:

In statics, your main task is to use Newton's First Law to solve most problems. While some described that the questions are on par or even easier than DSE Physics, one will need to consider that vectors are also deployed to solve 3D space questions, which may be unfamiliar with those who only acquainted them at the end of MATH1014. But for those who studied M2 in DSE (or equivalent subjects in other curriculum), life is boringly easy in MECH2020.

That said, they do teach you how to find the internal forces of trusses, and such questions do need specific methods, so you should nevertheless listen to some contents taught by Robin. Some of the course's content, particularly the methods on finding internal forces, is essential in your next semester's MECH2040.

In kinematics though, the contents are much complex than DSE Physics. You're often required to calculate relative motions, apply the more complex radial equations of motions, and so on. Also note that details are fatal, like if you miss that there are 2 strings in a pulley, you get wrong distance, and everything built on it screws up...

For those who spam questions for grades, you are advised to focus more on harder statics questions and dynamics questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ma (Robin) teaching is enthusiastic and patient. He keeps a slow and steady teaching pace, so that all students can catch up with the course content. While it's obviously boring or dull for an easy course, you'll likely thank for his teaching when he teaches more difficult MECH courses later.

Robin also have a grasp in maintaining the course's learning environment, he asks questions frequently, and for some occasions, said that will add bonus marks to those who answered correctly.

Speaking of our TAs, they are Mainland Chinese PG students, so one can imagine their heavy accents. Like MATH tutorials, they gave out questions to us, solve, and explain the questions to us. While my comment for them is that their teaching is generally mediocre, I do remember on one occasion that the TA-in-charge came upstairs to discuss a hard problem with me. I'll therefore make a honorable mention here.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 20% (95%, 80%, 100%, 100%, 100%)
Quizzes: 45% (100%, 100%, 95%)
Final: 35% (Never released)

As stated in the Workload part, with only 1 to 2 questions, the assignments are generally easy, though you should check your answers twice to avoid careless mistakes that cost you a lot. Quizzes are also not hard as well, and I suspect that the grading for quizzes are laxer than that of assignments. After all, according to Robin, the quizzes were designed to facilitate staged revisions.

Regarding the final exam, while someone previously reported that the questions were hard and tedious, this time the questions are all normal: no extra-hard questions, and I see a majority of students left early in the final exam. It is therefore quite likely that the previously reported harder questions are temporary measures for online teaching.

While it is reported that MECH courses are notorious for not releasing final results, and at the end I also didn't receive any such results, I get an A for MECH2020. That said, I can't ascertain whether this means good grading or is because of the simple contents, as Robin did say that all grades are distributed in accordance to the recommended range (aka pulling the curve).
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments are generally light and easy, with usually only 1 to 2 questions for us to solve. They're to be submitted within 1 week. While the quiz questions are generally on the same level of difficulty with assignment questions, so doing some extra questions by Robin is also sufficient.

If you want to prepare for the final, you are suggested to do extra challenging questions in the textbook. After all, most of the questions have fixed methods to solve, and aren't tricky. Questions involving unknowns are the hardest ones you'll encounter in MECH2020.
